title.text: Arabic Dialect Identification in Speech Transcripts

entities.text: Arabic Dialect Identification in Speech Transcripts

abstractContent.text: In this paper we describe a system developed to identify a set of four regional Arabic dialects (Egyptian, Gulf, Levantine, North African) and Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) in a transcribed speech corpus.
We competed under the team name MAZA in the Arabic Dialect Identification sub-task of the 2016 Discriminating between Similar Languages (DSL) shared task.

entities.text: Arabic Dialect Identification sub-task of the 2016 Discriminating between Similar Languages (DSL) shared task

abstractContent.text: Our system achieved an F1-score of 0.51 in the closed training track, ranking first among the 18 teams that participated in the sub-task.
Our system utilizes a classifier ensemble with a set of linear models as base classifiers.
We experimented with three different ensemble fusion strategies, with the mean probability approach providing the best performance.

introductionContent.text: The interest in processing Arabic texts and speech data has grown substantially in the last decade.
1 Due to its intrinsic variation, research has been carried out not only on Modern Standard Arabic (MSA), but also on the various Arabic dialects spoken in North Africa and in the Middle East.
Research in NLP and Arabic dialects includes, most notably, machine translation of Arabic dialects (, corpus compilation for Arabic dialects), parsing (), and Arabic dialect identification).
The latter has become a vibrant research topic with several papers published in the last few years (.

In this paper we revisit the task of Arabic dialect identification proposing an ensemble method applied to a corpus of broadcast speeches transcribed from MSA and four Arabic dialects: Egyptian, Gulf, Levantine, and North African (.
The system competed in the Arabic dialect identification sub-task of the 2016 edition of the DSL shared task () 2 under the team name MAZA.
